summary: An ex-con is lured back into the drug trade.

reviews.content:
Best fight scenes I ever seen. All fights are as it should be when performed from a highly trained killer, no half hour punch throwing when you have a knife .. don't use the knife if you have a gun.
Sure, some action fan viewers may say "If I want to see an action movie, I want to see as much fights as can deliver." I agree, but that does not mean that a guy should punch and kick another guy for half hour when he can just cut his throat with a knife in 3 seconds. Not in this movie. Here all fights are fast, clean and effective.
The more I see of Korean crime movies the more they seem the same.

This movie shows that thrilling and exciting action can be mixed with an actually meaningful and deeply touching story. 
America, take notes.

It doesn't get much better than this. Korean cinema has always impressed me, and rivals even Bollywood films that try their best (that conveniently made a poor knock-off version of this film). There needs to be a Korean Bollywood category for such iconic films; perhaps Koreallywood? It's an action movie with a heartwarming story, and it's a near perfect film. What's even more impressive, is that this was the second-only writing and directing credit for newb Korean filmmaker Jeong-beom Lee. Lee needs to be teaching film schools in Hollywood, because this is how a film should be made. This shames most Hollywood action films by seasoned filmmakers. The pacing is perfect, so the 2 hour runtime flies by. Every scene is perfectly captured with excellent cinematography. There's a perfect balance of the excellent choreographed action scenes, and the narratives that unfold along the way. Even the score and soundtrack were on point. All casting and performances were spot-on, and Lee was phenomenal in directing his cast, even the young ones. This film was recommended to me by another prolific IMDb reviewer in his 100 must-see films of all time. An excellent recommendation that I agree with. Newb filmmaker Lee is a genius, and this gem is a perfect 10/10 from me.

This motion picture, The Man from Nowhere, 2010 is written-directed by Lee Jeong-beom who makes this film with domestic-international success, South Korea's highest-grossing film in 2010...

Won Bin portrays grand and with the child star, Kim Sae-ron also good...

An incredible action movie. Great characters with a plot that is impossible to not be emotionally invested in. My only critic is that like many of its contemporaries at times it has scenes and actions that seem to serve more as shock value then providing actual value to the plot. Besides that though this film does not step a foot out of line and reminds us that action films can still be great.
its dark, its straight forward and its great!

really enjoyed it. i love revenge stories - especially when they're asian-made. they just do it SO well. i loved the premise, I loved the execution, & I loved the ending. & even after all that violence, i couldn't help but get incredibly emotional at the end. what a great movie. 10/10 recommend.

The Man from Nowhere (2010) - [Jeong-beom Lee]

I have been saying for a while now that the South-Korean Film industry is on a serious upwards trajectory. They are making many really cool films, and not just with Martial Arts movies. That being said I mainly have been watching their Action and Horror releases.

The Man from Nowhere is a typical Korean action film. They are a few decades behind Hollywood, and this is a good thing. They do not try to reinvent the wheel. Hollywood is so focused on "subverting expectations" that they seem to forget that media entrainment, for better or for worse, has already been distilled into stories and arcs that just work. Now sure some legend can break all the rules and make a fantastic film, but most people are not legends. Sticking to the guide lines can produce films that are enjoyable and comfortable for viewers. This is one such action film.

It is a well trodden action film path. The story is about a organ harvesting operation (this is the third film about gangsters killing people and stealing organs I have seen from Korea.. is this like a issue over there?). There is this mute, strange guy living in a flat.. minding his own business who befriends a mother and her child. Mother killed, child kidnapped... cue bone crunching, bullet spraying blood soaked rampage.

This is a pretty fun film, even though it is not very original and suffers from "foreign film aesthetics". What I mean by that is that after decades of watching US and US influenced cinema we are used to how they tell stories. Many Asian films (among other countries) simply do not follow those rules. This can make strange tonal shifts, make them hard to understand or a number of other things that can put off a western viewer.

But, even with that in mind, I still think this is a solid action film and well worth a look see. I think it is so good in fact, that I would be astounded if Hollywood is NOT trying to get a US Remake off the ground. Mr Nobody and John Wick are basically the same kind of film as this. If you like action films about a reluctant badass that takes out a small army of scum bag gangsters... then this one is worth adding to the pile.

Verdict : 'Cause you know every quiet recluse is a x-military, special op assassin, ninja policeman who has had his wife and children murdered in a brutal and ptsd inducing way.

This movie is extremely dark and upsetting. It doesn't shy away from any subject matter, but often has the decency to keep it just off-screen. Instead of an action-packed thrill ride like many of its peers this film has only a couple of fight scenes, preferring instead to dwell on the menace arising from the main character's inability to act in the face of depravity. The sparse action scenes are choppily constructed, making them hard to follow and exchange enjoyment of form for expression of tone. Still, it's coherent and well-told overall, so if you have no content aversion you may enjoy the meager, eventual catharsis.

Content warning: child abuse, organ trafficking

Closest comparison: It's like You Were Never Really Here by way of Oldboy.

Setting: Crime
Plot: Action
Tone: Horrific Tragedy
The best, brilliant, The original John Wick -Won bin is the best actor and please come back
What can I say…just wow! Brilliant film!

So well done.  Detailed.  Loved it.  And, something I have seen consistently - the child actors are professional and nail their parts every time.  Great action flick.  Found myself nervous and anxious even during a second viewing.
To make me cry isn't easy, but this certainly did. Won Bin is exceptional, and deserves all the praise for his performance, his emotions overflow.

WOW ok just WOW... This film takes you places i wasn't expecting...i m mean i pretty much knew it was gonna be great with 100# on here and 7.8 on IMDb... But still... The action...no the drama... Wait... The acting...the young girl... The main actor...the others just TOP NOTCH!  I cried many times in this flick... The connection with the main actors and their backstories... Was awesome.... But then the whole rest of the the plot.... A bit  confusing with all the characters... But worth the wait and conclusion 😭😭😭 FIVE BIG STARS UP 
           ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
The film that started my Korean movie fetish.

Even though the plot wasn't the most original out there, but the melee scenes were phenomenal. They did many things that other action movies didn't get right, which is in the accuracy of the fights. The cinematography was also done really well.

Decent revenge movie.  A bit confusing in spots.  I also didn't buy the bond with the girl - he dissed her for the whole beginning of the film, and when she gets taken, he goes after her like she is his daughter.  I can only assume he is supposed to have had a mental break and assumes it is his dead daughter.

I want to point out that if you are into Thrillers, revenge plots, and Korean vibes, this film must be part of your collection. Yes ! We all have seen kids in need for affection and protection like in "Leon". Revenge movies like "Old boy". Or ex-military that you don't want to mess with like "First Blood". But it is not about the theme, or even the plot, it is about the Visual Opera that unfolds before your eyes. The man from nowhere gets his noble roots from Samurai movies, Middle Age tales, or even Chinese WuXia. This Drama even symbolizes its Chevaleresque inspiration with a Knight Magic card given by the little girl to ask for protection. Some will just see a brawl with Home Depot furniture, but if you pass the language barrier you won't regret it !
An undisputed classic.  This film is incredibly well made.  Won Bin has maybe 10 lines in the whole movie and conveys so much through them.

This was one good Korean film, I liked it from start to finish. Don't be surprised of this film in getting a remake in American style film. I liked the attitude of the movie all leading to the fighting scenes were just great. Packed with great action, The Man From Nowhere becomes a solid good action film, As that being said for this being a good hidden gem, and delivering a good solid film that I enjoy, I give " The Man From Nowhere " a C.

I was literally blown away by this action-packed, suspenseful, and heart-wrenching  Korean film. Won Bin, the main actor, just nailed the s**t out of it. He played the man who barely speaks, but his violent urges and destruction speak for themselves. The more he kills, the less he speaks. But we, audience members, almost unavoidably find that this man is fueled by anger and sadness. Amazing camerawork. Phenomenal action. Top-notch performances from every actor and actress. This is an authentic masterpiece.

I think this movie deserves its four stars. It feels a lot for me like a Korean mix between Taxi Driver (1976) and John Wick (2014). It's dark, gritty, sad and pretty violent. An it's honestly a very good action/crime/thriller, showing us some of the harshest sides of humanity, and the movie also tackles a pretty upsetting theme of child anxiety and justice. All that soaked in buckets of enjoyable gore. Also, Won Bin gives a strong act as a grizzled and dark character. Overall, in terms of Korean films, this is one of the best movies I've seen in some time in that movie category. And for action fans, The Man from Nowhere is a must see. Recommended!!
This action-thriller is a wild ride of emotion and an example of tasteful fight scenes. Performances cut deep and make you root for them to come out on top. Also, this piece has an ending to die for!

Certainly not a unique plot, but it is definitely one of the better versions.  The telling of the relationship between the lead and the little girl, and its link to his back story, is just a little more believable than most.  Which makes his intensity and drive to find the little girl more believable.  The movie has good pacing, and the fight choreography is quite good.

The Man From Nowhere is an unexpected movie that fits well with action sequences and emotional tone. The performances and friendship of both Won Bin and Kim She-ron are perfect. The story is well made, while the finale was so sad that I wouldn't spoil it. Despite this movie has similar connections to other past and future action movies, this particular movie fits the bill. Overall, The Man From Nowhere is a perfect example of an action thriller movie.
I enjoyed this movie from start to finish. Gritty, yet stylish. It was very captivating.
A cool brutal Korean revenge action flick. It was pretentious and cliche but also pretty awesome. I didn't however like the editing and choppy cuts.

3.75*
This was really good.  It was well on it's way to being >4* but I didn't enjoy act 3 as much as I was expecting, given the ending.  I think it got too sappy at the end, and I think some of the bigger kills could've been more exciting/impactful.  But overall it's a solid movie and another asian revenge flick that puts our revenge films to shame.
The thrill, the suspense, the action, the tragedy, the beauty. This has it all but the way it is portrayed is just so authentic.
The rare kind of action movie that keeps you at the edge of your seat and pull on your heartstrings.
This is original John Wick with better feel of measure.
Awesome flick. Better than Taken or even the Bourne series. The South Koreans are where it's at for great action films with equally great stories and castings.
Tear jerker and thrill ride combined... very bloody, but very good
A watchable but sluggish and overlong Korean action thriller which starts and ends well, but sags in the middle.
simple yet fascinating
Bonecrushing and mean like usually only the Koreans can imagine it...i felt good entertained
The ending is what makes this movie.  Itï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)s a little slow to start, but is worth it in the end.  Itï¿ 1/2 1/2 1/2(TM)s all heart!!
Everyone should be required to watch this movie. One of my favorite films.
Seriously this is the best South Korea movie I've watched, I don't really like their movies, but I love this. Thumbs up to everyone that made this movie a success
Best of the man on mission type movie.

An incredibly violent, brutal, and visceral movie with a LOT of heart.

This movie feels like a passion project, it has a lot of beauty in it, but although sometimes it's executed in a bit of a clumsy and on the nose way. The cinematography here was surprisingly great, some really pleasing shots here. The music was pretty fitting, but used too much and not very subtly or creatively. The pacing stumbled a bit too.

The action, oh man, the action was insanely good. So fucking visceral and gritty, choreographed really well. The knife action was intense. Probably the best knife fighting I've ever seen.

Now the story starts out pretty simple, but gets a whole lot darker than I expected. Which is dumb of me to say, because I should know by now that Koreans aren't afraid to explore some really fucked up things in our world. The plot mostly makes sense, but some of the motivations are shown in a bit of a clumsy and blunt way. A bit more subtlety would probably work better.

Ultimately, it's a very satisfying movie that keeps you interesting, and makes up for it's shortcomings with a whole lot of passion. It left me with a good taste in my mouth, I didn't feel like the film was marred by it's somewhat clumsy execution at times. Another great Korean movie.

Edit: Forgot to mention the morbidly hilarious villains. Such over the top pure evil. One of them reminded me a lot of Patrick Bateman from American Psycho. Very fun character.

Many scenes could've been bad but they masked them well and made the movie watchable, there was only one bad fighting scene where they placed unnecessary knife sounds. 
The plot is good, acting is also really good and on top of that, story makes you feel all kinds of emotions, from sympathy, anger to sadness and happiness. 
I loved it (:
One of the best movies i hae ever seen

"Ajeossi" is kinda derivative - like a mixture of "Léon", "Oldeuboi" and "The Punisher" - yet very competently made. To be honest, it felt a little chaotic at times, but it maintained my interest and featured great action throughout, with the explosion, the knife fights and the bulletproof shield being absolutely memorable highlights. As for the closure, yes it was predictable, but it packed quite an emotional punch, so mission accomplished.

I have always been a fan of Korean directing.  The Man From Nowhere is a simplistic story line with a twist. Combining a roller coaster thrill ride of great choreography and drama.  Probably one of the best showcase of CQC (close quarter combat) and Arnis (Filipino martial arts).  The Director: Jeong-beom Lee, beautifully crafted each scene with quick cut scenes and raw camera angles that made you feel part of the story.  Bin Won or Won Bin who played Cha Tae-sik (The main hero/character) was so brilliant that you cant help but wonder about his past.  His calm demeanor  throughout the movie left a feeling of anxsiousness  waiting for his special forces moves to break out.  A great depiction of a ex special agent running from his past only to have it find him and test his every move.
A fantastic movie.  One of the best movies from asian cinema.
The very definition of mediocre. Bland storyline, bland characters, rhythmless action sequences shot so you don't see much and some below average acting.

The story and the portrayal of the Korean gangsters may be somewhat generic, but where 'The Man From Nowhere' really shines is with Jeong-beom Lee's fantastic direction and his seemingly innate talent for combining stunning visuals with the right combination of music to wring the most possible emotion out of any particular scene. Granted, there are a few instances where it seems a tad slow, and it could have done with a few more fight/action sequences here and there, but for the most part, it manages to overcome its shortcomings with a great final act and an overall engaging style.

a 10 year old girl, dark criminal underworld, a lonely pawnshop man.

The scene is set for a complex plot with unexpected twists and turns. There is a lot of color to the characters and it is very well shot. 
A pleasure to watch.

The movie starts very good; Telling a story that catches you; The viewer wants to know what is happening, he arrest you is this is good but in the middle is a little messy and although it seems that this in the movie is not what happened; The movie improves from half to end despite this and the final act is good; Soundtrack and photography are very good and the discoveries are sensational!

Action, story and revenge. A simple formula, although calculated in the best way possible as seen in The Man From Nowhere. I would recommend this movie in a heart beat if you haven't seen it yet. It grips you for the whole ride and expands into the character's back stories with a satisfying ending.
Solid Korean action revenge flick, 8.0/10

We've seen multiple films of this genre and despite being unoriginal in its ideas, The Man from Nowhere is stylish enough to be called a neo-noir. 
It's good to watch a straightforward film every now and then.
Entertaining, with visceral fight scenes and a fierce, understated performance from the lead actor. Stumbled upon this South Korean thriller and am glad that I did.
A crime thriller. Well choreographed action sequences but the story is not evenly paced. An entertainer for sure especially for those who crave for relentless action.
GREAT!! In the same vein as John Wick or Taken. I LOVE movies like this!

The Man From Nowhere follows a simple narrative, and excels in its action scenes, especially the final shootout, and ends up with an awesome and surprisingly emotional film, despite it being harrowing at the end.
Dark and Gore, typical of korean directors. It is very intense and sometimes painful to watch. Love it.
I cannot believe I have not heard of this movie before. One of those character-driven, sweet-vengeance story paired with spectacular acting.

Warning: Superlatives ahead. Watch this only if you love spot-on casting, amazing acting, fight scenes that are crisp and out-of-the-ordinary, and direction that is perfect whether the moment be terrifying or tender.

The director's hand is masterly, driving relentlessly in big action moments, then shifting gears from the infinite to the intimate when the smoke has cleared. The performances are moving and utterly convincing. The fight scenes are vivid and new, a pleasure to repeat-watch in detail - I always notice something new. 

The characters - whether good, bad, or ugly, or all of the above - are well-drawn, and the actors throw themselves into the roles with abandon. (The villains are particularly fun, and one, Hee-won Kim, seems to be making a fine career of it.)

The protagonist is a mysterious loner who seems to haunt his life like a ghost. The little neighbor girl is pulling him back down to earth, getting on his nerves and then getting under his skin. The child actor, Sae-ron Kim, is a natural talent who does a brilliant balancing act, making So-mi insistent, yet irresistible. Bin Won in the lead is a revelation - haunting, fierce, tender, as Tae-sik resists the agony of being recalled to life.

(Check out his other roles and see how completely he transforms from one to another. Takes my breath away!)

The acting is a treat - I re-watch scenes without the words, just to see how powerfully the actors do their jobs with the other tools at their disposal. It's wonderful how clearly you can tell who are the Feds, who are the home team Task Force, the Good Guys, the Big Bad, etc. - and what each side is after. It says a lot when the performances are eloquent even with subtitles turned off.

3.7/5

The Man From Nowhere has a strangely american feel to its directing which by itself wouldnt be a bad thing if it didnt sometimes feel like the movie isnt reaching its full potential, with every bit of originality feeling as it clashes with its blockbuster action intentions even if for the most part they are realized.
Despite its lack of originality, it is a well-made action film.

An excellent movie.  The acting was terrific all around, but especially the two leads. The cinematography was great and kept my eyes on the screen.  The action sequences are quick-paced and intense, often gory.  It's not the most original plot, but it certainly stands out amongst the genre.  Despite the two-hour plus runtime, there's never a moment that feels out of place.  It's also surprisingly moving.

Go for this action packed movie if you have a taste for dark shades in movies. Won Bin sparkles as a silent, yet clinically lethal ex-commando......Not meant for weak minds for the presence of  bloody scenes. The film keeps you glued although the ending is not very unpredictable. The last scene is touching......and Won Bin looks sexy when he is brooding with those long hair hanging over his face

Gritty and action packed film, reminded me a little of Leon. Great film and the cast are all well served by the creative teams. The ending was a little corny but after everything before it you can let it slide.
Reminds me of John Wick, but with more drama and touching moments.

It has been called a mixture between Leon: The Professional, and Taken. However, this film is much more than that. Amazing acting by Won Bin, a great original score, and of course, amazing fight sequences. This movie blends drama and action with perfection. You need to watch it ASAP.
Great fight scenes from Bin Won. Action grip movie with a touching tearful ending. See it

Cha Tae-Sik is a wonderful character with a dark past. Won Bin (Autumn in My Heart, Korean Drama) is the actor I believe carries this film in the same direction of all similar films like Luc Besson's "The Professional", and the late Tony Scott's "Man on Fire". Actors like Denzel Washington and Jean Reno didn't go through circles on their rampage that dealt greatly in their tragic characters, but this film takes us through all the feels, and doesn't let us forget the cold and dark world it portrays. Director Jeong-beom Lee (Cruel Winter Blues) makes great strides with subtle action scenes that are still wonky, BUT SO FUCKING FUN! I think Won Bin is the best part, and you don't need to go crazy for him, all the other characters in this crime drama are great. The cops aren't incompetent and the bad guys are not pushovers. We may may want to save the young girl, but sometimes the protagonist has to save himself.

A Clint Eastwood knock off ... style if from Clint's spaghetti western days ... think the art school is 30 years behind ... but tried and true formula .... need Jason Statham or Bruce Willis, Chou Yun Fat would have been nice..

The Man From Nowhere, is an intense movie. With more then just enough
of the blood. Very well edited and marvelously acted movie. However,
it's kind of movie which would have worked better with lesser of the
words. At times it felt very expressive. Especially when characters
would express their emotions using words. The title lost it's
justification somewhere between those dialogues which brought him form
nowhere into open book category. Fight sequences are intense and very
well choreographed. Cinematography is good too. Writing could have been
little better though.

Generally a good revenge/chase movie.

With a magnetic leading man whose demeanor and look almost carries the film by itself combined with excellent cinematography (lighting sets a strong look and the camerawork is exciting and simple yet stylish), THE MAN FROM NOWHERE excels in areas that we expect it to (action, thriller, tenseness) and falters in areas that we hoped it would not but still does (cliche story, some caricature villains). The visual style in this Korean thriller is top-notch and truly elevates the film while a few lighthearted filmmaking moments provide enough comedic relief to add fun to what is otherwise a dreary premise - from the brilliant execution of our protagonist jumping out a window and landing in seemingly one shot, to the deft action and fight scenes that unravel in a no-bullshit manner, and to instances of very appreciable dialogue (most by our main villain) during moments where viewers are probably thinking the same thing (one example occurring during a car ride in which the villain is on the phone with our protagonist and calls out the moments of silences and the eventual hang-up - a fun strategy by director Lee Jeong-beom to diffuse overly dramatic tendencies). Won Bin is electrifying in his role - his performance is muted but painful while aided by sharp costume design that increases the presence (and coolness) of his character. It has its flaws and head-scratching moments, but overall, this film is a strong addition to South Korea's growing list of powerful and riveting revenge crime thrillers.
It's not the most original story, but it's still well made.

If you've seen movies such as 'Taken' then you may be getting bored of the rescue-the-girl format and drug dealer villains but 'Man from Nowhere' makes up for its familarity with slick fighting skills, dark elements and amusing english dubbing. The blood soaked finale is satisfyingly reminiscent of the slick action from 'The Raid'; however it also serves as a reminder for what much of the early parts were missing since the movie keeps the protagonist's highly trained combat ability relatively hidden until the end. Still a very good action thriller but it is the reason why it misses out on what would have otherwise been a certain 4 stars.
Another outstanding revenge movie from South Korea.
That excellent movie,amazing amazing wow,That story , how sad end,this movie the need another story, My respect for actors and directors amazing great job wow wow..

A dark but refreshingly touching re-telling of the classic revenge thriller. Strong acting performances (esp. Won Bin) create compelling relationships between the characters, and the action sequences are fast and beautifully shot, allowing the viewer to feel every punch and every slash of a knife. The Man From Nowhere is well worth the watch, especially for fans of films such as Taken and Leon: The Professional.
An underrated and awesome action movie with incredible action sequences, good performances, a good story, and some emotionally powerful scenes.

Beautiful cinematography & directing coupled with a real-time pace makes this  road-weary story line worth the watch. It's a S L O W burn, but a nice spin on the genre.  Available on Netfilx (Subtitiled)

I have never reviewed before and I am not a native English speaker. So please bear with my English. I may be new to rotten tomatoes as a reviewer but not new as a consumer. I've been using rotten-tomatoe reviews as a reliable guide for picking what to watch. I was surprised that this movie received 100% rating and hence decided to watch it in full. I have never seen a more 'bollywoodish' movie made by another film industry every before. Nope its not a complement. Too cliched, used and abused  every movie trope possible and very poor action sequence compared to other east Asian flicks. I don't understand what made the other reviewers gave it a 100%. I am surprised. I just hope that the rating for this movie is the last surprise  RT has for me.

The Man from Nowhere supplies more than enough drama and bloody-good action to make for a compelling film but what really drives it home is its riveting direction. The film is able to display the emotional, vivacious and authentic storytelling that  is a clear developing sign of Korean cinema. 4/5

This Man From Nowhere may not have the best characterization or plot, but its gruesome action, striking cinematography, and overall burning sensation of vengeance throughout was so captivating that I couldn't bring myself to even care about its low points. This is bar none the best revenge flick that I've ever seen.

Still in Progress.... 

Right off the bat, you cant help but notice the comparisons to "Leon The Professional." Little girl befriends quiet unsuspecting next door neighbor who turns out to be the quiet yet ultimate killing machine. But that just about where that comparison ends and the comparison with "Taken" begins. What do both these film have in common? They were written and or directed by Luc Besson. The French writer and director known for his visual and stylish action revenge thrillers. The  Bin Won, who we remember as the mentally challenged Yoon Do-joon in Bong Joon-ho's masterpiece thriller "Madeo" (Mother). The transformation from his character in "Madeo" to his character in "The Man From Nowhere" is impressive to say the least.

Perhaps one of the most simply yet wonderfully executed crime thriller films from any country. Everything from the action to the acting fits together in a well crafted puzzle that does not rely on intricate plotting or overblown martial arts set pieces, but the power of human emotion. Leading man Won Bin and little Kim Saeron deliver in one of the best Korean films to grace cinema.

One of the best Korean revenge films ever! "A bittersweet life" and "I Saw the Devil" and this one adds up to that list. A very humane story added up with a bone crunching "The Raid" like action and we have this. Superb performances from the actors and definitely hollywood is having a sight seeing for a remake. A must watch as this one really gets you in. Perfect 5 out of 5.
An exceptional movie.  Fantastic fast paced direction, brilliant action sequences and a charmingly sweet story of redemption and retribution. Wonderful acting. Worth every single star.

This movie is so unlike any stereotypical Hollywood Thriller. It is action packed, entertaining, shocking, bizarre, and yet it still has a nice message underneath all the crazyness. It is without a doubt an amazing movie and I recommend it everyone to watch it. So far, no one I have recommended this movie to has been disappointed.
Any one who loves action movies will love this one! Must see!!
Exactly what i expected

I abhor violence and I hate revenge, which is exactly why I loved this movie. This is an action movie where the "hero" acts out of desperation and devotion to another person. It's an action movie that holds its main character to a high regard, not just because he's a good fighter but also because he is the only character in this world with the ability to put the life of another person above his own.

This is an action movie that lives in a realm of cinema far beyond the same old Hollywood schlock we get every year in America. It's a movie that sets up a central character that you actually hold in high regard as a human being. He isn't a simple-minded ex-marine or ex-cop who can't control himself. He's the kind of action hero we need to have in American cinema, one with morals.

Also, I'd be lying if I said that this film didn't have spectacularly directed action.

It's a masterpiece of Korean action cinema that is fluidly directed, exceedingly well acted, beautifully written, and very exciting.

I couldn't have possibly loved this movie more! I hope tired franchises like "Taken" and "The Expendables" are taking notes.
excellent film, good fight sequences, well paced, recommend seeing
While I was expecting more in the way of martial arts, this movie was throroughly entertaining from start to finish. I was expecting "the Raid" and got "taken" (but much smarter and more well done.)

A movie that I turned on as a filler for my day off, morphed into a surprisingly fantastic film. So much so, that I re-watched right after. The movie has a perfect balance of action and plot. It seems very slow at first but then they give you a taste of the action within roughly 5 to 8 minutes of the film. From there it takes you through a journey that you wish the Taken series could accomplish, with pursuit of a young child taken from this mysterious pawn shop owner. Awesome movie.

The South Korean cinema has turned movies centered around the theme of vengeance into a macabre, unique art form, from Park Chan-wook's thematically diverse The Vengeance Trilogy, to Kim Ji-woon's bleak, hyperviolent I Saw the Devil (2010); The Man from Nowhere falls somewhere in between these movies. Pawnshop owner Cha Tae-sik lives a sombre, linear life, and finds comfort in an uncanny friendship with So-mi (Kim Sae-ron) and a cactus plant. Seen by those in his apartment complex as a possible gangster and a sex criminal, Tae-sik's life is simple until So-mi's mother becomes entangled with an illegal operation between two South Korean gangs, where one of them eventually coming after both So-mi and her mother, which Tae-sik is inadvertently dragged into.

The Man from Nowhere is one of those movies where the antagonists gradually realize that they've just ****ed with the wrong guy... and continue ****ing with the wrong guy. By no means is Won Bin at Iko Uwais or Donnie Yen's level, but when it comes down to it, he is able to unleash a flurry of punches and kicks to the vital points of his enemies as the mysterious Cha Tae-sik, who rarely smiles or says anything beyond three lines at any given time, which seems to be the biggest downfall of the character, but that really isn't saying much considering the other characters are ostensibly written worse than Tae-sik and are all nothing more than forgettable villainous caricatures of South Korean cinema.

While it is a slow-burn action movie that takes its own sweet time teasing the viewer before going for the jugular in the final act, director Lee Jeong-beom proves that he knows how to craft an action flick as watching The Man from Nowhere makes one thing blatantly clear; other similar movies released after it have clearly taken cues from this movie and expanded on them. The Man from Nowhere's premise is similar to The Equalizer's (2014), and it has a scene that is nearly identical to Denzel Washington's first fight scene in the movie, though ironically The Equalizer didn't adapt this movie's wide shots during the close-quarter sequences, instead opting for klutzy torso hugging camerawork. Additionally, The Man from Nowhere features a kerambit-wielding antagonist similar to The Raid 2: Berandal (2014), both in appearance and utility, and it even features a fight scene similar to Berandal's kitchen scene, though Gareth Evans took his version of it to a much more elaborate and visually brutal degree.

Solid action/thriller that while not original, manages with some great action sequences & brutal edge.  The cast is solid across the board, with Bin Won providing a compelling lead performance, along with competence in the numerous action scenes.  Behind the camera, Jeong-beom Lee crafts a slick action film, with brutal fights & a harsh look at the criminal underworld so that when Tae-sik deals out his vengeance, it almost seems righteous.  The film isn't original, with two-dimensional criminals and there is a fake-out at the end that seems unnecessary.  Nevertheless, a great viewing and further example of how good South Korean cinema has gotten.

Korea comes out with some pretty good action thrillers when they want to.  Decently choreographed and with a story that isn't all that foreign from fans of the genre, think Leon the Professional, The Man From Nowhere really fits a lot in during its two hour time frame.  While the acting tends to venture on the silly side from some of the supporting cast, the main actor isn't asked to stray much with his emotions as the hardened ex-military-cop-turned-pawn-shop-owner.  There are some good hand-to-hand combat scenes with a little more gunplay than the former, but when it comes to gangster flicks from the East, it's pretty solid.  With plenty of revenge to fuel the film, outside it's brief slowdown about an hour in and an unclear bad guy from the first act, it settles in nicely with emotion and grit for any art house adventure flick.

One of the best Korean revenge films ever! "A bittersweet life" and "I Saw the Devil" and this one adds up to that list. A very humane story added up with a bone crunching "The Raid" like action and we have this. Superb performances from the actors and definitely hollywood is having a sight seeing for a remake. A must watch as this one really gets you in. Perfect 5 out of 5.
Yet another stylish and violent thriller from Korean cinema.

Feels styled after an anime movie and plays out as one of the best action movies I've ever seen. The direction even bears some resemblance to Nicolas Winding Refn's own style, which is not a bad thing at all. Any cons are just nitpicking.
Another Masterful thriller from Korea, solid story and visceral action
Another great movie from Korea.
Movie is incredible, thrilling and emotional. A lot of great elements, great movie!
Top notch, one of the best action movies I've ever seen
The US has Taken, Korea has The Man from Nowhere. I say it's a fair deal.

89%
Saw this on 22/8/14
This Korean film has got all that is needed for being a good action film. It's got good action, special effects( a rarity for the Asian films), acting and story. Even after being an action film, it tries to be thought provoking. It never withholds any suspense, but it keeps the viewer hooked up to the screen more than the much touted films of the genre.
Awesome movie! one of my favorites
Even though the shadow of 'Man on Fire' looms heavy on this Korean film, The Man from Nowhere has its own strengths... And yes, as is expected from a Korean action film, more violence, more gore...

amazing movie it is well shot. their were some scenes where it had me going wow thats awsome. even though the story has been told before this movie makes the whole revenge and child getting taken story great, and makes taken look like a kids movie.
I am amazed that this flew under my radar. Most fun i've had watching a movie in a long time.

It's one of those movies with a cliché plot that sounds similar to a Liam Neeson or Jason Statham film. People will not be blown away by the action scenes, they will be captivated by the performance from the main lead who does an incredible job emoting his acting with his eyes.
Great flick.  Good plot, good acting and it has all the moves it needs to hold your attention.  One of the best ending fight scenes ever for the best me up genre.
A well acted thriller with some excellent action scenes. All the acting in the film was good and I liked that the film was more tonally even than some of the other Korean films I have seen.
Cliche, but it's still more artistic than most of action films.
Easily has some of the most gripping fight scenes.
YAAAASSSSSS!!! CRINGE CRINGE CRINGE all the way through. So violent, heartbreaking and badass at the same time. Korean movies are the best.
What a great movie!!! Awesome from start to finish
If you wanted to know what 'Taken' would be like in Korea, here you go.
Like those dark themed Korean action films but quite as dark as OldBoy?  This is film is along the lines of Taken but probably done a bit better.  Very much worth your time.

Brave in story and violence but feels empty in emotion. This movie is entertaining with abundant gun, knife and hand fight. The right choice to choose Won Bin as the main character. But it still not a good reason why this man gave his effort to save unknown child.

An excellent and intense action movie. It's got  great story, cinematography,  action, acting. Like nothing about this disappointed me at all. It's such a crazy good movie. I loved every minute of the movie. Totally worth watching.

A fantastic, and surprisingly nuanced film. This isn't strictly a martial arts film, it's more of an action/thriller where the characters happen to use martial arts when the action does happen. And not the silly wire-based kind. This is the grounded, tendon slicing, bone breaking, wince inducing kind. 
The story is tight and the characters are actually given time to breathe, especially in the opening hour which is mostly action-free. Now this might drive away viewers searching for something like the Raid, but if you stick with it, the slow burn start makes the finish all the more spectacular. After spending the majority of the film getting to know these characters, every punch, kick and knife slash carries weight, and the climax will leave you breathless.
A solid thrilling film!

Great story, wonderful screenplay, amazing soundtrack, heart touching performances and makes hollywood movies look like a school play. To sum it up this is one of the best asian films I have ever seen.

Mom kicked a garbage can when she got pregnant with me.

A pawn shop employee meets a little girl and they become best friends.  The pawn shop owner has a violent past that he has spent most of his life trying to overcome; however, when the little girl is kidnapped by a child smuggling ring, the violent past resurfaces as the pawn shop worker sets off on a mission to rescue the girl.

"You came to save me."
"Stay there.  You'll get blood on you."

Lee Jeong-beom, director of Cruel Winter Blues, delivers The Man from Nowhere.  The storyline for this picture is fun to watch unfold.  It actually reminded me of Jason Stathom's Transporter movies a little.  The action was intense and plentiful and the acting was pretty solid.  The plot was just okay and a bit cliché but has a great ending.  The cast includes Bin Won, Kim Sae-ron, Kim Tae-hoon, Kim Hee-won, and Kim Seong-oh. 

"Jump him as a group.  He's one strong bastard."

I watched this off Netflix because I adore these Asian action pictures.  I was impressed with the scores this movie has been receiving on rottentomatoes and I can tell you I enjoyed this picture, but actually thought it would be a little better based on the reviews.  This was entertaining for sure, and I would definitely recommend seeing this, but this isn't an all time classic like the scores may lead one to believe.
